section.p: Through the prism of the comparison, this study examines the dialogism characterizing the discourse of French literary critics in the second half of the 19th century. Using an automatic method, a set of comparisons relying on terms belonging to eleven predetermined hard sciences (anatomy, biology, physics, chemistry, botany, zoology, astronomy, surgery, medicine, geology, and mathematics) was extracted in a corpus of 249 French critical texts as well as in novels, philosophical texts, scientific texts, and texts from the social and human sciences. Apart from confirming the separation of literary critics into two tendencies, one which distances itself from sciences, and the other which wants to emulate it, the retrieved comparative constructions show that despite this division, some sciences such as mathematics are mostly depicted negatively in relation to literature. Furthermore, the comparison plays a crucial role in conferring a scientific dimension to literary criticism, especially because it enables to create an analogical system around some scientific concepts such as ‘espèce’ and therefore, to classify, discuss, and scrutinize literary forms more rigorously. In this literary discourse, the comparison does not merely borrow terms from scientific disciplines but also imbue them with new meaning, so that literary criticism can acquire the same legitimacy as sciences without losing its intrinsic features.

div.p: The 19th century in France (1789–1914) witnessed profound social, political, and scientific changes that clearly affected the literary production of that period which not only reflects the social mutations taking place as well as the struggles for identity of the young French nation but also, in the case of Zola’s naturalism, chooses to draw inspiration from science to study and depict human beings as truthfully and as realistically as possible. In fact, with the unprecedented popularity of Darwin’s and Spencer’s evolutionism, of experimental medicine, modern biology, and the principles of thermodynamics among the public, the scientific discourse is no more solely restricted to a small number of specialists. On the contrary, it fosters social, ethical, and aesthetic transformations within which literature redefines its essence. It is, therefore, not surprising that the influence of science seems more predominant in contemporaneous literary criticism, as exemplified by manifesto-like titles such as Deschanel’s Physiologie des écrivains et des artistes (1864), Ghil’s Méthode évolutive instrumentiste d’une poésie rationnelle (1889), Huret’s Enquête sur l’évolution littéraire (1891), and Renard’s La Méthode scientifique de l’histoire littéraire (1900). Furthermore, this deliberate introduction of terms borrowed from so-called hard sciences (biology, physics, chemistry, botany…) in the literary discourse coincides with the emergence of French literary criticism per se, a unified, legitimate, and autonomous discipline: before that, as Thibaudet (1930) notes, there were criticisms, but no criticism. If its object of study, literature, remains unchanged, this new literary criticism clearly relies on this dialogic discourse to break free from the label of ‘belles-lettres’ and to affirm itself as a truly scientific endeavor.

First developed by Bakhtin, dialogism refers to the idea that in prose some words create a dialogue between the actual work in which they are found and previous works. Consequently, a correct reading of these words and any text that contains them must necessarily consider how their meaning has been shaped by their past contextual usages and by other authors’ intentions. As dialogism denotes a discursive choice that connects and contrasts families of texts, it constitutes an ‘interdiscourse’ and should, therefore, not be confused with the intertext which merely corresponds to the presence of parts of a given text X in another text Y (Adam, 2006).

In this respect, the present paper seeks to explore the ‘interdiscursive dialogism’ exemplified by literary criticism borrowing from the sciences, i.e. to examine the interactions taking place between, on the one hand, the literary discourse, and, on the other hand, the scientific discourse, at the level of their structure, their respective components, their socio-historical role, and their limits as scholarly activities. For this purpose, as a figure of speech that creates a parallel between a priori unrelated entities by highlighting their differences and resemblances, the comparison appears to be an adequate linguistic tool to dissect this juxtaposition of discourses. Moreover, regarding the kinds of relationships they establish and the various functions they can fulfil, comparative constructions have a lot to say about an author’s beliefs and vision of the world.

To get a broad view of the impact of comparisons on the literary discourse, an automatic method was used to extract and analyze the relevant comparisons in a corpus of French critical texts published in the 19th century. While the first part of this article presents the different corpora compiled for this experiment, the second part focuses on the extraction method. Then, we present and discuss the results obtained in terms of their ideologic and pragmatic significance.

The texts forming the corpus of French critical texts were all taken from the online critical corpus (‘Corpus Critique’) of the Labex OBVIL, an online library which provides digitized versions of the main texts that shaped French literary criticism from the 17th century onward in various formats.1 A total of 249 texts penned by 63 literary critics were collected for the specific period this study is concerned with, regardless of whether they scrutinized drama, poetry, or novels. Fig. 1 gives an overview of the distribution of the corpus. While half of the authors have only one text in the corpus, works by five critics in the remaining half (Jules Barbey d’Aurevilly, Charles Augustin Sainte-Beuve, Jules Lemaître, Émile Faguet, and Alphonse de Lamartine) amount to more than 40% of the whole corpus.

To confirm the role played by comparison in critical texts and to contrast this discourse with contemporary discourses, four additional corpora were built: a corpus regrouping philosophical texts, a corpus of scientific texts, a corpus of texts that belong to the social and human sciences, and finally a corpus of novels, which being written in prose, are discursively closer to critical and scientific texts than plays and poems. For the three first corpora, French translations of foreign texts were also included. In addition to the Labex OBVIL’s database of critical texts, other online libraries offering freely downloadable digitized texts, such as the Internet Archive,2 the Gutenberg Project,3 and the Bibliothèque électronique du Québec,4 were consulted (Table 1).

div.h2: 3 Automatic Extraction of Dialogic Comparative Sentences
div.p: A comparison generally stresses the extent to which two things are identical or different, by posing one as superior, inferior, or equal to the other. In rhetoric, this can fulfil several purposes such as to clarify, embellish, contrast, or vivify (Caplan, 1954). In addition, while some comparisons, so-called literal comparisons, are ‘scientific’ in the sense that the elements compared are ‘the same in kind’ (Bain, 1890), other comparisons are labeled figurative because they create a mental image by associating entities from distant semantic domains. This study mainly deals with the first type of comparison and, especially, with the implication that even though, strictly speaking, the elements compared belong to different types of discourse, through comparison they are either assimilated as being equivalent or on the contrary, irrevocably dissimilar.
In this respect, a sentence such as ‘La sensation varie comme le logarithme de l’excitation’ (É. Durkheim, Cours de philosophie, 1884) would be analyzed as:

To effectively capture the introduction of elements of the scientific discourse through comparative constructions in the various corpora, we decided to extract only sentences in which the standard of comparison belonged to one of these eleven predefined scientific domains: ‘biology’, ‘medicine’, ‘chemistry’, ‘anatomy’, ‘surgery’, ‘botany’, ‘zoology’, ‘astronomy’, ‘mathematics’, ‘physics’, and ‘geology’. The following points motivate this choice:
unlike the comparee, the standard of comparison is always present in retrieved comparative constructions and is necessarily expressed with a common noun;
the comparison mining algorithm (Mpouli and Ganascia, 2015) used for this experiment has a higher precision and recall (above 90%) for identifying the standard of comparison; and
we ran the comparison mining algorithm on a subcorpus of 137 critical texts. From the 26,228 resulting sentences, we manually selected a sample of 132 dialogic comparative sentences, annotated in terms of the domains with which their comparee and their standard of comparison are generally associated: ‘science’, ‘art’, ‘literature’, and ‘other’. From this mini-experiment, it can be concluded that, as far as critical texts are concerned, the head noun domain of the standard of comparison is a far more reliable indicator of dialogism between scientific and literary discourses (Table 2).

Before explaining how the retrieved comparative sentences were automatically filtered, based on their standard of comparison, the next subsection briefly summarizes the comparison mining algorithm used.

According to Friedman (1989), processing comparative sentences by computers is a challenging task because of the various forms a comparison can take in natural languages. Nonetheless, in recent years, the automatic mining of comparative sentences has garnered a lot of attention, as it could greatly benefit to the detection of the opinions voiced in consumer reviews (Jindal and Liu, 2006a and b; Niculae and Danescu-Niculescu-Mizil, 2014; Xu et al., 2011). Most of the methods proposed, however, tend to be restricted to specific types of comparisons, looking for only one comparison in each sentence or ignoring the inherent syntactic and semantic complexity of comparative constructions. In contrast, the rule-based algorithm for simile identification presented in Mpouli and Ganascia (2015) has been developed specifically for literary texts written in French and gives all plausible scenarios for each identified comparative construction. For instance, in the sentence ‘Descartes, Pascal, Fermat sont des géomètres plus encore que des physiciens.’ (Renard, La Méthode scientifique de l’histoire littéraire, 1900), the proposed comparee will either be ‘Descartes, Pascal, Fermat’ or ‘géomètres’.

In a nutshell, three main steps are observed for the automatic extraction of comparative constructions:
preprocessing tasks such as tokenization, lemmatization, part-of-speech tagging, and sentence segmentation;
the extraction of potential comparative constructions and of the standard of comparison; and
the identification of the remaining components of the comparison.

Since comparisons are always linguistically recognizable by the presence of a marker, a list of potential markers of comparison in French was established with not only conventional markers such as comparatives of degrees and ‘comme’ but also verbal phrases, adjectival phrases, and prepositional phrases (Table 3).

Since the sentence ‘Les parotides sont plus petites que les maxillaires dans les tatous et les paresseux.’ (G. Cuvier, Leçons d’anatomie comparée, 1800–05) can be interpreted as an abbreviated form of ‘Les parotides sont plus petites que les maxillaires dans les tatous et les paresseux sont petits’, it is possible to conclude that comparative constructions are built using two mirror clauses and that there is a correlation between the role of each element and its grammatical function. As the two only elements that must always be present in any comparative construction, the marker of comparison and the standard of comparison play a crucial role in the detection process. As a matter of fact, a sentence is a potential comparison if it contains one of the selected French markers of comparison and if a noun-headed noun phrase immediately follows that marker or is separated from it by a parenthetical phrase. Then, the verbal or adjectival ground is retrieved and will be subsequently used as a clue to identify the comparee.

The detection of the components of each potential comparative construction relies on syntactic chunks and hand-crafted rules. These rules not only define the possible structures the potential comparative construction may have but also serve to decide the grammatical function of words surrounding the marker (see Fig. 2 for an overview of possible syntactic structures of comparative constructions).

div.h2: 3.2 Semantic filtering of retrieved comparative constructions
div.p: Although a lot of research has been done on automatically clustering words by their distribution in language or by their hypernym, identifying the semantic category or domain of a word often remains problematic, mainly because of the fuzziness of semantic categories, polysemy, and metaphorical meanings. However, the domain of usage of a word is traditionally an item of information that is recorded in dictionary entries, especially as far as the technical terms are concerned (Fig. 3).

Among the freely available machine-readable dictionaries of the French language, Le Dictionnaire Électronique des Mots (Dubois and Dubois-Charlier, 2010)5 was selected for this experiment because it synthesizes various paper dictionaries and systematically provides in each entry the semantic domain of the corresponding lexeme as well as other semantic information, which makes it possible to narrow down the extraction to the main scientific concepts of that period (Fig. 4).

As its name implies, Le Dictionnaire Électronique des Mots (Dubois and Dubois-Charlier, 2010) is first and foremost a database, which could explain the abbreviated form chosen to encode the information it contains. It consists of 145,198 entries describing 115,714 monolexemes and 12,946 multiword expressions, for a total of 32,199 adjectives, 72,609 nouns, 16,086 verbs, 6,731 adverbs, and 1,026 interjections.6

Since all the predefined sciences are used as domains in the dictionary, it seems straightforward to build a domain-specific vocabulary by simply extracting all the nouns under these domains. However, such a method would bring about some noise; for example, it would include, in the resulting vocabulary, all body parts and organs (hand, heart, finger, nerve…) which, though frequently used in comparisons, tend mainly to introduce an image and are seldom used with a scientific connotation. In addition, some words are polysemous and can be classified under more than one science. Finally, the dictionary is far from being perfect: the term ‘espèce’ which plays a crucial role in the 19th-century scientific discourse is only associated with the domain ‘relation’ (Fig. 5), and some common nouns are recorded solely as adjectives (Fig. 6).

Literary historians generally divide French literary criticism of the second half of the 19th century into two main tendencies. On the one hand, there is a tradition of literary criticism strongly influenced by positivism which seeks to break free from the tradition of belles-lettres and aspires to be a scientific discipline built on the same model as objective sciences. On the other hand, born in reaction to the growing rationalization of literature stands a so-called impressionist literary criticism tradition which defends a subjective approach to literature based on individual feelings and the pleasure derived from reading.

Undoubtedly, the ideas expressed in the extracted sentences confirm this clear separation of literary critics into two antagonistic sides as regards their treatment of scientific discourse. At one end of the spectrum, various critics condemn the dryness and the arrogance of scientific discourse, and by doing so, reinforce a romantic and symbolist vision of literature: the comparison induces the superiority of literary discourse.

In contrast, at the other end of the spectrum, several authors describe scientific discourse as being not only equal to literary discourse but also able to enhance it, as shown in the comparisons in Table 6.

This second trend regroups critics such as Sainte-Beuve, Brunetière, Guyau, Taine, Hennequin, Littré, Lemaître, Goncourt, and Zola, in other words, a ‘scientific’ literary criticism which borrows methodological and cognitive models from emerging sciences to endow the literary discourse with an epistemological dimension. In this respect, the comparison plays a discriminatory role, as it distinguishes distinct currents in literary criticism depending on the relationship they establish between literature and scientific disciplines.

All sciences, however, do not have the same status. In fact, their depiction in the corpus differs significantly. For instance, ‘zoology’, the second scientific domain with the least number of terms, is largely predominant and covers more than 30% of the retrieved comparisons. This prevalence of terms from ‘zoology’ in the critical discourse could undoubtedly be explained by the pre-eminence of life sciences which develop themselves from Lamarck to Darwin and which, unlike other scientific disciplines, have succeeded in acquiring an authoritative status. However, ‘zoology’, as introduced by literary critics, leaves little room for re-evaluation: it is mostly used as an exogenous discourse whose validity is never questioned (see Table 7).

Consequently, exploring the corpus of French literary criticism texts through comparisons makes it possible to pinpoint how each science is discussed in relation to literature and what kind of imaginary it conveys. In addition, the comparisons extracted automatically in the four synchronic corpora identify certain phenomena specific to this period as well as some idiosyncratic characteristics of the French literary criticism discourse.

By comparing the raw distribution of scientific domains in the corpus of critical texts and the corpus of French novels (Fig. 8), two crucial observations can be made. First, the persistence of the predominance of zoology, with the term ‘espèce’ being the most frequently used, shows both the rise of zoology in the 19th century and its extreme popularization which made it accessible to the common people. Second, literary criticism distinguishes itself by a more homogeneous distribution of the different domains: apart from medicine, physics, mathematics, and chemistry also contribute to create comparative constructions, so forming a more comprehensive interdisciplinary dialogue.

Whereas French literary criticism redefines and incorporates scientific concepts into an aesthetic discourse, in sciences, most extracted constructions are pseudo-comparisons that strengthen a demonstration. Void of any evocative power, they do not have any symbolic function and exclusively add more weight to the author’s reasoning (see Table 11).

In this respect, the obtained results clearly demonstrate the heuristic role of analogy in the scientific thinking of that time. In fact, at the beginning of the century, comparative anatomy propounds the idea of a structural homology between living beings, as exemplified by Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire’s theory of the ‘unity of composition’ which states that animals’ organs are not dictated by their function and environment but result from a unique plan which, once unveiled, will explain their internal structure. Knowledge of the world is therefore subjected to similitudes established via comparison. Behind this heuristic method, which was progressively extended to all living beings, obviously lies the phantasm of a universal harmony and of a unified complex world (see Table 13).

This peculiar conception of comparisons can also be found in the corpus of critical texts, specifically in positivist writers. By borrowing this analogical principle, which appears to be able to order all heterogeneous phenomena, through comparison, these critics will analyze literature or human beings on the same model as living beings. The comparison is, hence, perceived and exploited as a key element of a scientific nature of the discourse.
div.h2: 5 The Construction of an Analogue Model
div.p:
It would of course be reducing to limit our study of the use of comparisons in literary criticism to merely observe the transfer of some lexical items from one discourse to another. In rhetoric, because of their suggestive power, comparisons are often used to give more weight to an argument. If various usages of the comparison can be found among the extracted sentences, they all follow the same discursive strategy: the image created by drawing a parallel between the literary object and the exogenous element taken from the scientific domains adds a rhetorical flavor to the scientific discourse. In this respect, incorporating scientific concepts through analogy into the literary discourse constitutes another way of making the meaning of an utterance less specific which can then be exported to other domains. In addition, various scientific terms are more noticeable because they are more frequently used as standards of comparison. To better analyze these terms, we have borrowed from Stengers (1987) the idea of ‘nomad concept’: as soon as a transversal concept migrates from one science to another and by extension, from one domain to another, it becomes in part reinvented by the type of discourse in which it finds itself and constructs new knowledge. Naturally, in this context, the use of the term ‘espèce’ is far from being trivial. Since Linné, ‘espèce’ has constituted the basis for morphological classification frameworks that rely on homology. At the beginning of the 19th century, Cuvier (1817) derives its definition of ‘espèce’ from ‘variety’: the meeting of individuals that have one another or common parents as ancestors, and of those that resemble them as much as they resemble each other. As a basis for classifying living beings by opposition to inorganic beings, the concept of ‘espèce’ gains more and more importance during the 19th century, as biology becomes an autonomous discipline. Moreover, because of its position at the center of a matrix of resemblances and homologies that is always evolving toward encompassing the whole universe, it appears, at the theoretical as well as the lexical level, the ideal starting point of any analogical system.

Although the term ‘espèce’ was initially applied to the description of fauna and flora, under the influence of Darwinist anthropologists, this sense changes to refer to the ‘espèce humaine’, as illustrated by Quatrefages (1861) who writes in his seminal book L’espèce humaine: ‘l’anthropologie a pour but l’étude de l’homme considéré comme espèce’ (the subject of study of anthropology is man considered as a species). As it can designate human beings, and consequently, individuals, groups, and populations, the concept of ‘espèce’ is particularly adequate when one is sketching a typology and regrouping elements that share the same features. Its shift from the natural sciences to the human sciences generalizes itself in the last third of the 19th century in such a way that it embodies the triumphant imagery of that time, which gravitates around a new representation of the living.7 In this sense, the term ‘espèce’ plays the role of a ‘nomad concept’ (Stengers, 1987). Since in discourse, it is principally used in relation to the living and the organic, it inspires multiple parallels between life sciences and other domains, and serves as a point of reference which supports a new epistemological operation, and foremost the merging of various fields of knowledge (see Table 15).

Thinking about a literary species in the same way life sciences treat animal or plant species makes it possible for literary critics to have at their disposal a complete theoretical arsenal: literature, reintroduced as a natural and organic phenomenon, encompasses an infinite number of varieties, countless forms, and innumerable manifestations that can now be analyzed, explained, and classified, as shown by Brunetière in the comparisons (see Table 16).

It is worth noting that sciences, and more particularly natural sciences, received considerable institutional backing which elevated them into authoritative models. Charle (1990), for example, insists on the unique place that sciences occupy in the world of scholarly studies, some decades before the figure of the ‘intellectual’ starts catering to the needs of the literary field: the authority to conquer a dominant position in literary or intellectual circles came from the new source of legitimacy represented by science and consequently from its incarnation, the scientist.

Besides, using the resemblances established through comparisons, the literary critic can treat literature like science treats its object: through the power of analogy, literature and art become knowledge fields. In a nutshell, science functions as an ‘analogue model’ (Black, 1962) which validates the project of literary criticism, and subsequently operates an axiological reversal by giving to the literary discourse the value of truth, to which its aesthetic and ethical values are subordinated.
div.h2: 6 Comparison at the Core of the Rivalry between Science and Literary Criticism
div.p: Apart from unifying different discourses, the comparison also opposes them. Unlike metaphor, it does not map the target and the source term, but rather relies on a dual movement of imitation and differentiation that keeps the compared elements in competition. The fundamental difference between these two tropes needs to be highlighted, since the literary critics of our corpus seem to use comparison more readily than the metaphor to give a scientific dimension to their discourse. Moreover, comparisons in the corpus of French critical texts are never combined with metaphors.

It is possible, of course, to suspect that positivist literary critics distrust the metaphor because of its lyrical nature, and in general, refuse to associate the scientific discourse with images that could block or distort reality. The reason that prevails, in our opinion, is the explicit rivalry that the comparison establishes between the scientific and literary discourse. By creating analogical parallels, literary criticism seeks not only to borrow missing structures but also to reject the domination of the sciences; it builds and demolishes a model at the same time. Thus, the generated comparisons differ from scientific comparisons which, according to Girard (1978), prefer acquiring concepts to assimilate them. Once science is erected as an authoritative model used to validate the literary discourse through analogy, it becomes a ‘rival model’ (Girard, 1978) in the sense that its complete supremacy ontologically threatens literary criticism: while the domain that surpasses the other must keep the term which has then lost all its worth, the defeated domain can no more regain that term which seems invaluable. Thus, through comparison, literary criticism poses itself as a rival of science which consequently acquires the status of model. In fact, if critics yearn for scientific roots and mimic the scientific style by using scientific terms, they nonetheless reject science as a ‘rival model’, so that literary criticism does not draw any legitimacy from science, but rather from itself.

Therefore, by simultaneously summoning and keeping the sciences at bay, literary criticism consolidates its bases in the epistemological sphere created by the scientifico-literary dialogism and reaffirms its literary singularities (see Table 18).

To conclude, the discursive dialogism established by the comparison takes part in the construction of the identity of the literary discourse. The structural analogy first gives to literary criticism a partial identity, but it is truly by distinguishing objects, differentiating the comparee and the standard of comparison that the literary discourse can afterward acquire its own identity and free itself from other domains. This role of the comparison is directly related to the first function of comparison defined by Foucault (1966): help to distinguish objects through their similarities and mainly their differences.

In this respect, the scientifico-literary dialogism actively participates in the birth of a new discourse on literature, which validates and emancipates itself via a necessary clash with the scientific model.

This article has attempted to study the role played by comparisons in shaping the discourse of French literary criticism in the 19th century. The automatic method used reveals the important place that the comparison occupies as a catalyst for an interdiscursive dialogism. As a matter of fact, the comparison has significantly contributed to the validation of the French literary criticism of the 19th century. The introduction of terms borrowed from hard sciences mainly stresses the fact that the identity of a new discourse is achieved first through imitation and then through differentiation. Thus, to paraphrase Ricœur’s (1990) comment on the impact on the other on the construction of meaning, scientific discourse does not only constitute another facet of literary discourse but also contributes to its evolution.
